cover.title: Partisan Press Era and Objective Reporting
cover.instructions: To open this flipbook, simply select the edge of right side of the book's cover. To advance pages, simply select the right, or left, side.

flipbook.page:
Though newspapers gained freedom after the American Revolution, they remained in what is known as the partisan press era. The partisan press era was a time when newspapers mixed opinion with fact in their news stories as part of their normal reporting. No longer forced to please the politicians in power, reporters experienced new freedoms in their writing. The result was different from the colonial newspapers because publishers and reporters could support or oppose candidates as they wished in their news stories.

The partisan press era lasted from the late 1700s until around the start of the Civil War.

flipbook.page: What did newspapers do during the partisan press era?

As the young United States matured, the newspaper industry learned that the American people demanded "regular" news—not just partisan news, but information that would be useful to everyone. As a result, publishers began to move toward today's model of American journalism: objective reporting. Objective reporting separates fact from opinion. Using this method, impartial reporters provide the news in one section of the newspaper, and opinionated writers discuss their views in a different section. This model enabled publications to reach even larger audiences, as anyone interested in current events could read the paper without running into heavy bias.
